author: Kevin Pang
title: Eat this: Fried pizza at Fiamme
text:
What we're talking about when we talk about pizza is, really, the crust. Toppings matter, of course, but the baseline for critiquing pizza is on merits of dough and cooking method. Think about it this way: If you don't have a good crust, you don't have a good pizza, no matter what's on top.
In Naperville, the 3-year-old Fiamme adheres to the strict guidelines of Neapolitan crusts: double-zero flour, an 800-degree brick oven that produces blistering pies in less than two minutes. But I'm drawn to the restaurant because of a seldom-seen variant called montanara, or pizze fritte â€” or, in more alluring terms, fried pizza.
What happens here is pizza dough gets flash-fried for 45 seconds before getting finished in the oven for 75 seconds. That quick fry puffs up the interior and gives the pizza a crisp chew, reminiscent of Native American fry bread. It also adds a richness that reminds me of a buttery breadstick. Fried pizza: It's a wholly Italian concept that seems wholly American. Fiamme, 19 N. Washington St., Naperville, 630-470-9441 , fiammepizza.com . There are two pizzas listed under the "pizze fritte" heading, but the fried option is available with any toppings.
